resources.name: Metropolitan Police (UK) advice about how to report rape and sexual assault
Metropolitan Police (UK) provides advice on what happens after you report a rape/ sexual assault
Victim Support (UK) provide confidential and free information on how to get support information on reporting rape and sexual assault
If you need help understanding how to report sexual violence, this Rape Crisis (UK) guide can help you
Rights of Women (UK) provides comprehensive guidance on reporting sexual assault to the police

processMap.name: Different ways you can report the assault to the police
processMap.text:
Time: 1hr - 3hrs

If you feel comfortable, you or someone you know should report the assault to the police. This can be done in a number of ways: 

- Phone 101 or 999
- Report the assault online at https://www.met.police.uk/ro/report/ocr/af/how-to-report-a-crime/
- Visit police station - https://www.met.police.uk/advice/advice-and-information/rsa/rape-and-sexual-assault/how-to-report-rape-and-sexual-assault/
- Visit a Haven: https://www.thehavens.org.uk/contact-us/
- Provide information anonymously through Crimestoppers

Your safety will be the most important thing. For non-emergency cases they may ask you about how they can make contact with you again. If you are living with the suspect you can make arrangements to speak to an officer without the suspect knowing about it, at a time convenient to you. If the sexual violence occurred recently you may be asked whether you need any medical treatment and be advised on how you can preserve evidence. 

Source: Met Police, https://www.met.police.uk/advice/advice-and-information/rsa/rape-and-sexual-assault/what-happens-after-you-report-rape-or-sexual-assault/
Date checked: 10.11.2019

Source: More ways to report than call & police station: https://www.met.police.uk/advice/advice-and-information/rsa/rape-and-sexual-assault/how-to-report-rape-and-sexual-assault/
Date checked: 7.11.2019

Source: Rape Crisis UK, https://rapecrisis.org.uk/includes/media/From-Report-to-Court-a-handbook-for-adult-survivors-of-sexual-violence.pdf#page=54

processMap.name: Your first police interview
processMap.text:
Time: 2-5hrs

As soon as possible after you report rape or sexual assault, the Police will arrange for a uniformed officer to talk to you. Their first priority will be to check on your welfare and find out if you need any emergency medical assistance.

You ask to be spoken to in a comfort suite. Comfort suites are dedicated rooms where victims of rape and serious sexual assault.

Interview questions asked:
Who did this?
What happened?
Where did it happen?
When did it happen?

FAQs
Waiting time before officers can interview you: ?
Can someone accompany me? 
Who would be involved?

Source: Met Police, https://www.met.police.uk/advice/advice-and-information/rsa/rape-and-sexual-assault/what-happens-after-you-report-rape-or-sexual-assault/
Date checked: 10.11.2019

checklist.text: The Police will arrange for a uniformed officer to talk to you.
Your interview happens in a private room or comfort suite.
If the sexual violence occurred recently you may be asked whether you need any medical treatment and be advised on how you can preserve evidence
A dedicated officer may be assigned to your case.
You are referred you through to specialist support advocacy services, such as Independent Sexual Violence Advisors.
Your dedicated officer will take a detailed account from you in the form of a written statement or a visually recorded interview.
Your officer will keep you informed of how the investigation is going at least every 28 days or sooner if there are any updates.
Your dedicated police officer refers to victim support organisations such as ISVAs and/or Haven.
If needed, you were referred to the forensic medical examination.

resources.name: Rape Crisis (UK) advice on where to see medical support to gather evidence to support your case
If you need to know where to access medical support after rape/ sexual assault NHS (UK) can direct you

processMap.name: How you can get a medical exam without involving the police
processMap.text:
Scenario:
-------------------------------------------------------
-------------------------------------------------------- 

*ADDED AS A SEPARATE CARD*

1) If you go to the police-
- Police officers who attend incidents of sexual violence should have an early evidence kit with them (to preserve evidence; cannot replace a full medical examination; needs consent)
- If you have contacted the police, they may take you to the SARC 

-------------------------------------------------------
-------------------------------------------------------- 

2) Independently -
- You can go to a SARC independently without contacting the police

3) No police, no SARC - 
You can get medical treatment by visiting your local hospital accident and emergency department or by going to see your GP.

(If you decide that you do want to report the incident you will be put in touch with a specially trained police officer. The services provided by SARCs are free, confidential and entirely independent from the police and other agencies in the criminal justice system.)

checklist.text: As a result of the examination, the doctor will produce a report about the investigation in terms of samples taken from you and observations made.

If the decision to prosecute is made at a later stage, the specific doctor who examined you and the forensic scientist together will have to provide written statements and may be required to attend court to give their statements about the medical examination.
In case of sexual violence, the Police officers should have an early evidence kit with them and/or they can take you to the Sexual Assault Referral Centre (SARC)

The forensic medical examination cannot take place without your consent. You have the right to ask to be examined by either a female or male FME. By agreeing to the forensic medical examination, you are agreeing to the results and the evidence gathered to being given to the police.
You have the right to be accompanied by a family member or a friend during the medical examination if you wish. It is also possible to ask for an interpreter if you need one!
If you have washed before you have the examination, the doctor may still find physical evidence.

A good idea to take a change of clothes and underwear with you to change into after the examination. Because the clothes you were wearing during the incident may be evidence, they may not be returned to you until the criminal proceedings have ended.

processMap.name: If the initial report was by a third party then the police will take a detailed account from them
processMap.text:
Time: [?]

In an instance where the sexual assault was reported by a third party then the police will need to take a detailed account from that person. This can be in the form of a written statement or a visually recorded interview. They’ll talk through both of these options with you beforehand.

Source: 
Rape Crisis UK, https://rapecrisis.org.uk/includes/media/From-Report-to-Court-a-handbook-for-adult-survivors-of-sexual-violence.pdf
Date Checked: 10.11.2019

checklist.text: If the assault was reported by a third party, police will interview them.
Police will collect as much physical evidence as they can.
Police may call you back for further interviews to review information.
Police may request your help in identifying the suspect
The suspect(s) may be arrested
Once identified, the suspects(s) will be interviewed.
Any third parties who may have information relevant to the case will be interviewed.
Police decide to pass the case to the CPS.
Police decide to close the investigation without charging.

processMap.name: The decision to charge the suspect(s) is taken
processMap.text:
Time: [?]

Description
The CPS, in most circumstances, takes the decisions to charge the suspect(s). After considering the evidence, the CPS uses a two-stage test to come to a decision. The first stage is the 'evidential stage' where the CPS considers whether there is adequate evidence to demonstrate a realistic prospect of conviction. The second stage or the 'public interest stage' takes into account whether it is in public interest to prosecute.

The police, on the other hand, only applies the 'evidential stage' of the test to make the decision to charge or discontinue the case.

processMap.name: Alternatives to charging
processMap.text:
Time: [?]

Description
The suspect may be provided with the option to accept a caution for the offence. If the offender accepts the same, the case cannot go to court. It will become a part of the offender's criminal record. You cannot appeal against the administration of a caution. You can, however, make a complaint to the police about the same.

processMap.text:
Time: [?]

Description

checklist.text: The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) assign a specialist lawyer to review your case alongside a second lawyer.
They review all the evidence gathered to determine whether or not to prosecute the case.
The first question they answer is "Is there enough evidence to prosecute?"
The second question is "Is it within the public's interest to prosecute?"
A prosecuter may in rare cases want to meet with you before making any final decisions.
The suspect is charged and the case proceeds to trial.
The suspect is not charged and the case is dropped.
The suspect is cautioned rather than prosecuted (usually reserved for minor cases).
The CPS will write to you to inform you of any decisions.
You have the challenge the decision made by the CPS and can lodge a formal request with the Right to Review.
If you have the means available, you may choose to take up a private prosecution if a criminal prosecution was dropped / unsuccessful.
